narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is a great introductory course to screenwriting. The class covers the developing of characters, formatting structure, collaborating with others, etc.

I refined my skills on screenplay structure and learned a lot about how to be as concise as possible in writing stories. I also gained a lot of valuable insight from other writers and exposed myself to a lot of material.
The basic format of screenwriting. Main things: don't use adverbs. Write visually. Sluglines (INT./EXT. Location - Time). Use three dashes.
skills for writing and evaluating screenplays. Writing coverage.
I learned how to format a screenplay correctly and how to write pitches. It was useful to learn how to do script coverages too.
Screenwriting skills, knowledge of how to craft characters in a story

This course was incredibly beneficial as an intensive introduction to screenwriting. I learned a lot about writing for film and tv, but also about the business of screenwriting and the paths people take to find success. It was an incredibly insightful class led by a passionate professor!
Learned how to format a script as well as practical advice regarding what goes into effective writing (such as avoiding adverbs, how to format montages, etc).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A great thing about this class is the collaborative environment Marc encourages. After workshopping with your fellow peers and getting your script cold read in front of the class, you will much better understand the weaknesses/strengths of your craft. The professor gives great detailed feedback, and it's just overall a LOT of fun.

I think the smaller screenwriting groups was a good way to structure the class so that people got more than just one class a week out of the class. I also think the final assignment was very doable considering time constraints. However, the time between which the last few students got to workshop their scripts and when the final script was due was very short, which I thought was unfair, so if there was a way to restructure the class so that more time is allotted, that'd be great. I also think the midterm folder is a bit excessive in its requirements although I do see the value in all of the assignments required.

Strengths: Prof Lapadula is a fantastic professor. There was not a ton of guidance on the story until after we had written a first draft. He's very good at the technical side of writing. He also has a very specific sense of humor. But he's super chill. I really liked having the weekly unsupervised small groups meetings. Those were great. Learned a lot from my peers. Weaknesses: Pretty much your entire grade is the midterm folder/final. If you cannot pace yourself throughout the first half of the semester with the amount of writing required for the midterm folder, be wary of this class. I felt the communication was poor. For the final, no one knew the date it was due. So one person asked and just like told everyone else. I feel like having set dates at the beginning or at least emailing everyone when the date was decided would be a good idea. Granted, this was the covid spring semester when there was no spring break so the dates were a little weird. So, I guess be proactive and ask.
Engaging and interesting lectures. I enjoyed the format of the class but hoped there would be more instruction on how to structure an interesting screenplay.

Strengths: workshops, learn how to format, sub-groups, guest speakers

Weaknesses: Maybe more detail on how to structure a story, sometimes seminar feels like it's going a bit off topic
There should be more classes
The strengths of this course mainly lie in the enthusiasm of the professor and how effectively he created a community environment that facilitated our improvement as writers.

Strengths: extremely engaging lectures. Prof Lapadula makes classes fun but still gives you tons of practical advice. You get to have the class read your script multiple times, so there are plenty of opportunities to get personalized feedback on your writing. Weaknesses: You're assigned to meet with a group outside of class, so we ended up meeting via Zoom. This was extremely valuable, but it was hard to keep people accountable. It's easy for the group that you're put into to stop meeting since you're supposed to organize that outside of class. Those sessions helped get even more individualized feedback, so just make sure you all keep that going for as long as possible.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the class was not affected by its virtual component. The structure and content were there.
N/A
This class worked well on zoom.
Online lectures worked fine.
They were all successful! In particular, the sub-group meetings were a great way to get to know people during the pandemic!

We were probably shown less clips (which is typical of film classes) because of the Zoom format. Overall, the classes were very engaging. My only concern was the lack of breaks since this was a 2 hour class and we usually were sitting just looking at the screen the whole time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely encourage people who are even slightly interested in screenwriting to take this class. You start having highly interesting self-dialogues as a writer and the class will allow you to embark on your journey as a storyteller. It was one of the highlights of my semester.

I would definitely recommend this course to someone who is just starting writing. It is very introductory and doesn't assume that you know more than you do. Also, none of the students felt like they were too advanced, so there was no pressure or insecurity in that sense.

This is a great class if you're interesting in learning the format of screenwriting. It's a cool opportunity to have a practical creative writing class where you get feedback from your peers and get to learn from listening to their scripts too.
Yes. I think the class is a great way to learn how to write screenplays.
Yes, if you want to learn how to format and interact with other screenwriters. Also good because the class creates a space where you can really plan and focus on your screenplay.
Yes, it's challenging and inspiring
I would!! It is a great and intensive introduction to screenwriting; you will learn a lot in a short period of time and be impressed by what you can accomplish!

YES!! It was my first experience with screenwriting and actually helped me fall in love with the craft more than I would've expected. It's amazing how many opportunities you get to share your work with others and have really personalized feedback. Prof Lapadula even calls you to go through your entire midterm folder with you (so you know he reads everything) and talks you through ideas for your script.
